abstract.p: Actor and philanthropist Paul Newman addresses graduate Contemporary Philanthropy class at University of California's Haas School of Business; photo (S)

block.p: Is that Paul Newman at the head of the B-school class? Sure enough, one day last week, the blue-eyed box-office legend was advising budding moguls on how to give -- even before they make their millions.

This semester, the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley is offering a new one-credit graduate class called ''Contemporary Philanthropy.'' It covers the giving of time, money or both.

Is that Paul Newman at the head of the B-school class? Sure enough, one day last week, the blue-eyed box-office legend was advising budding moguls on how to give -- even before they make their millions.

This semester, the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley is offering a new one-credit graduate class called ''Contemporary Philanthropy.'' It covers the giving of time, money or both.

''The school recognized this is a subject that would be useful to our students,'' said M. Frances Van Loo, an associate professor of business administration who teaches the course. ''Some of our students do become super-rich overnight.''

Mr. Newman spoke to the class on Thursday, offering advice gleaned from his many years of giving away money: through his Newman's Own line of salad dressing, sauces and popcorn, he has donated more than $100 million, all of its profits since its founding in 1982, to charity.
Ms. Van Loo said she planned to ask other big givers, as yet unnamed, to speak to the students soon.
